turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Mike, why are you cutting me out of the action?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Tom, we're going to be legitimate all the way, and you're the legal man.  What could be more important than that.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: I'm not talking about that.  I'm talking about Rocco Lampone building a secret regime.  Why does Neri report directly to you, rather than through me or a caporegime?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Bookkeepers know everything. Rocco's men are all a little too good for the jobs they're supposed to be doing.  They get a little more money than the job's worth.  Lampone's a good man; he's operating perfectly.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Not so perfectly if you noticed.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Mike, why am I out?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You're not a wartime Consigliere. Things may get tough with the move we're trying.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: OK, but then I agree with Tessio. You're going about it all wrong; you're making the move out of weakness... Barzini's a wolf, and if he tears you apart, the other families won't come running to help the Corleones...

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Christ, Tom; I needed more time with him.  I really needed him.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Did he give you his politicians?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Not all...I needed another four months and I would have had them all.  I guess you've figured it all out?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: How will they come at you?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I know now.  I'll make them call me Don.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Have you agreed on a meeting?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: A week from tonight.  In Brooklyn on Tessio's ground, where I'll be safe.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I've never seen anything like it.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I told you I had a lot of relatives.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Michael, what are those men doing?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: They're waiting to see my father.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: They're talking to themselves.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: They're going to talk to my father, which means they're going to ask him for something, which means they better get it right.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Why do they bother him on a day like this?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Because they know that no Sicilian will refuse a request on his daughter's wedding day.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No.  His name is Luca Brasi.  You wouldn't like him.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Who is he?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You really want to know?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Yes.  Tell me.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You like spaghetti?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: You know I love spaghetti.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Then eat your spaghetti and I'll tell you a Luca Brasi story.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Once upon a time, about fifteen years ago some people wanted to take over my father's olive oil business.  They had Al Capone send some men in from Chicago to kill my father, and they almost did.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Al Capone!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: My Father sent Luca Brasi after them.  He tied the two Capone men hand and foot, and stuffed small bath towels into their mouths. Then he took an ax, and chopped one man's feet off...

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Michael...

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Then the legs at the knees...

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Michael you're trying to scare me...

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Then the thighs where they joined the torso.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Michael, I don't want to hear anymore...

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Then Luca turned to the other man...

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Michael, I love you.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: ...who out of sheer terror had swallowed the bath towel in his mouth and suffocated.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I never know when you're telling me the truth.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I told you you wouldn't like him.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: He's coming over here!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Tom...Tom, I'd like you to meet Kay Adams.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: How do you do.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: My brother, Tom Hagen.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: If he's your brother, why does he have a different name?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: My brother Sonny found him living in the streets when he was a kid, so my father took him in.  He's a good lawyer.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I didn't know your family knew Johnny Fontane.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I used to come down to New York whenever he sang at the Capitol and scream my head off.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: He's my father's godson; he owes him his whole career.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: We have something for your mother, for Sonny, we have the tie for Fredo and Tom Hagen gets the Reynolds pen...

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: And what do you want for Christmas?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Just you.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: What will your father say?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: As long as I tell him beforehand he won't object.  He'll be hurt, but he won't object.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: What time do they expect us?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: For dinner.  Unless I call and tell them we're still in New Hampshire.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Michael.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Then we can have dinner, see a show, and spend one more night.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Michael, what are you doing?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Shhh, you be the long distance operator.  Here.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Hello...this is Long Distance.  I have a call from New Hampshire.  Mr. Michael Corleone.  One moment please.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Would you like me better if I were a nun?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Would you like me better if I were Ingrid Bergman?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Michael?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I'm thinking about it.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Michael...

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No, I would not like you better if you were Ingrid Bergman.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Hello.  Kay?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: How is your father?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: He'll be OK.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I love you.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I LOVE YOU.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Yeah Kay, I'm here.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Can you say it?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Tell me you love me.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I can't...

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Please say it.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Look.  I'll see you tonight, OK?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Visiting hour ends at eight thirty. I'll just sit with him; I want to show respect.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Can I go to the hospital with you?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I don't think so.  You don't want to end up on page 3 of the Daily News.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: My parents don't read the Daily News.  All right, if you think I shouldn't.  I can't believe the things the papers are printing. I'm sure most of it's not true.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I don't think so either.  I better go.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: When will I see you again?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I want you to go back to New Hampshire...think things over.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: When will I see you again?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Goodbye.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I have to see my father and his people when we get back to the Mall.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Oh Michael.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: We'll go to the show tomorrow night--we can change the tickets.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Don't you want dinner first?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No, you eat...don't wait up for me.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Wake me up when you come to bed?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Your sister wants to ask you something.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Let HER ask.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Why are you so cold to her and Carlo?  They live with us on the Mall now, but you never get close to them.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I'm busy.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Connie and Carlo want you to be godfather to their little boy.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Will you?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Let me think about it, O.K.?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Michael, it's not true.  Please tell me.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Don't ask me.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Tell me!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: All right, this one time I'll let you ask about my affairs, one last time.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Is it true?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I'm Michael Corleone--this is my father.  What happened to the detectives who were guarding him?

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Oh your father just had too many visitors.  It interfered with the hospital service.  The police came and made them all leave just ten minutes ago.  But don't worry.  I look in on him.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You just stand here one minute...

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: You cannot stay here...I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You and I are going to move my father right now...to another room on another floor...Can you disconnect those tubes so we can wheel the bed out?

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Absolutely not!  We have to get permission from the Doctor.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You've read about my father in the papers.  You've seen that no one's here to guard him.  Now I've just gotten word that men are coming to this hospital to kill him.  Believe me and help me.

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: We don't have to disconnect them, we can wheel the stand with the bed.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: I was worried when we couldn't get in touch with you in that hick town.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: How's Mom?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Good.  She's been through it before. Me too.  You were too young to know about it.  You better wait outside; there're some things you shouldn't hear.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I can help you out...

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Oh no you can't, the old man'd be sore as hell if I let you get mixed up in this.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Jesus Christ, he's my father, Sonny.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Theresa.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: All right, Mikey...who do we have to hit, Clemenza or Paulie?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: One of them fingered the old man.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Clemenza?  No, I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: You're right, kid, Clemenza is okay. It was Paulie.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: How can you be sure?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: On the three days Paulie was sick this month, he got calls from a payphone across from the old man's building.  We got people in the phone company.  Thank God it was Paulie...we'll need Clemenza bad.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Is it going to be all-out war, like last time?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Until the old man tells me different.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Then wait, Sonny.  Talk to Pop.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Sollozzo is a dead man, I don't care what it costs.  I don't care if we have to fight all the five families in New York.  The Tattaglia family's going to eat dirt.  I don't care if we all go down together.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: That's not how Pop would have played it.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: I know I'm not the man he was.  But I'll tell you this and he'll tell you too.  When it comes to real action, I can operate as good as anybody short range.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: All right, Sonny.  All right.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Christ, if I could only contact Luca.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Is it like they say?  Is he that good?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: To the city.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Send some bodyguards.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I don't need them, Sonny.  I'm just going to see Pop in the hospital. Also, I got other things.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Sonny...Sonny--Jesus Christ, I'm down at the hospital.  I came down late.  There's no one here.  None of Tessio's people--no detectives, no one.  The old man is completely unprotected.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: All right, get him in a different room; lock the door from the inside. I'll have some men there inside of fifteen minutes.  Sit tight, and don't panic.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I won't panic.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Mikey, you look beautiful!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Cut it out.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: The Turk wants to talk!  The nerve of that son of a bitch!  After he craps out last night he wants a meet.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: We can't wait.  No matter what Sollozzo say about a deal, he's figuring out how to kill Pop.  You have to get Sollozzo now.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: The kid's right.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Go on Mike.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: They want me to go to the conference with Sollozzo.  Set up the meeting for two days from now.  Sonny, get our informers to find out where the meeting will be held. Insist it has to be a public place: a bar or restaurant at the height of the dinner hour.  So I'll feel safe.  They'll check me when I meet them so I won't be able to carry a weapon; but Clemenza, figure out a way to have one planted there for me.  Then I'll kill them both.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Why don't you stop living like a bum and get this place cleaned up.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: What are you, inspecting the barracks?  You ready?  Did Clemenza tell you be sure to drop the gun right away?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: A million times.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Sollozzo and McCluskey are going to pick you up in an hour and a half on Times Square, under the big Camels sign.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: O.K.  How long do you think before I can come back?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Probably a year...

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: I'm glad you came, Mike.  I hope we can straighten everything out.  All this is terrible, it's not the way I wanted things to happen at all. It should never have happened.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I want to settle things tonight.  I want my father left alone.

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: He won't be; I swear to you be my children he won't be.  Just keep an open mind when we talk.  I hope you're not a hothead like your brother, Sonny.  It's impossible to talk business with him.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: We're going to New Jersey?

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Most important...I want a sure guarantee that no more attempts will be made on my father's life.

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: What guarantees can I give you?  I am the hunted one.  I've missed my chance.  You think too highly of me, my friend...I am not so clever...all I want if a truce...

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Is it all right if I go to the bathroom?

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Do you pledge to guide and protect this child if he is left fatherless? Do you promise to shield him against the wickedness of the world?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Yes, I promise.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Do you renounce Satan.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I do renounce him.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: And all his works?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I do renounce them.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Do you wish to be baptized?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I do wish to be baptized.

turns.speaker: TESSIO
turns.text: Barzini's people chisel my territory and we do nothing about it.  Pretty soon there won't be one place in Brooklyn I can hang my hat.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Just be patient.

turns.speaker: TESSIO
turns.text: I'm not asking you for help, Mike. Just take off the handcuffs.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Be patient.

turns.speaker: TESSIO
turns.text: Let us fill up our Regimes.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No.  I want things very calm for another six months.

turns.speaker: TESSIO
turns.text: Forgive me, Godfather, let our years of friendship be my excuse. How can you hope for success there without your strength here to back you up?  The two  go hand in hand. And with you gone from here the Barzini and the Tattaglias will be too strong for us.

turns.speaker: TESSIO
turns.text: Barzini wants to arrange a meeting. Says we can straighten any of our problems out.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: He talked to you?

turns.speaker: TESSIO
turns.text: I can arrange security.

turns.speaker: MOE
turns.text: Mike, good to see you.  Got everything you want?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: MOE
turns.text: The chef cooked for you special; the dancers will kick your tongue out and you credit is good!  Draw chips for all these people so they can play on the house.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Is my credit good enough to buy you out?

turns.speaker: MOE
turns.text: Buy me out?...

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: The hotel, the casino.  The Corleone family wants to buy you out.

turns.speaker: MOE
turns.text: The Corleone family wants to buy me out.  I buy you out.  You don't buy me out.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Your casino loses money.  Maybe we can do better.

turns.speaker: MOE
turns.text: You think I scam?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You're unlucky.

turns.speaker: MOE
turns.text: You goddamn dagos.  I do you a favor and take Freddie in when you're having a bad time, and then you try to push me out.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You took Freddie in because the Corleone family bankrolled your casino.  You and the Corleone family are evened out.  This is for business; name your price.

turns.speaker: MOE
turns.text: The Corleone family don't have that kind of muscle anymore.  The Godfather is sick.  You're getting chased out of New York by Barzini and the other families, and you think you can find easier pickings here.  I've talked to Barzini; I can make a deal with him and keep my hotel!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Is that why you thought you could slap Freddie around in public?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You straightened my brother out?

turns.speaker: MOE
turns.text: Hell, he was banging cocktail waitresses two at a time.  Players couldn't get a drink.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I have to go back to New York tomorrow.  Think of your price.

turns.speaker: MOE
turns.text: You son of a bitch, you think you can brush me off like that?  I made my bones when you were going out with cheerleaders.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Do you recognize my voice?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: I think so.  Detective squad?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Right.  Don't say my name, just listen.  Somebody shot your father outside his place fifteen minutes ago.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Is he alive?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: I think so, but I can't get close enough.  There's a lot of blood. I'll try to find out more.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Find out anything you can...you got a Grand coming.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: How do you do.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: What are you doing in Mongi?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: You should come and have lunch with us, before you go -- Dickie?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Sure. Any time.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: And be careful in the sun. Your gray's in danger of turning a little pink.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Sorry, sorry, sorry. I know, I'm late, I'm a swine.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Did you forget where I live? It's four o'clock.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I just woke up. I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: You just woke up!

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Fausto and I -- we took the boat out, we were fishing, and then it was dawn and we'd caught absolutely nothing.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Well, we ate everything without you.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: We?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Yes, Tom Ripley's here.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Tom was telling me about his trip over. Made me laugh so much I got a nosebleed.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Is that good?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Shut up!

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I'll do it. I make a fabulous martini.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Everybody should have one talent.  What's yours?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: What? What?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Meet my father, Herbert Richard Greenleaf 1st.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Uncanny!

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I don't get it.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Hi Tom.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Marge, Ripley's saying goodbye.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I'll come down.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Did you speak to my father?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Okay, we're going to Naples. There's a club, it's not a club, it's a cellar.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: It's vile.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Yes, it's vile. Don't worry, you don't have to come.  It's great. You're going to love it.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: It'll just be for a little while. He can be... he makes me laugh.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Okay, darling.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: You'd say if you mind?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: No, I like him.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Marge, you like everybody.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I don't like you.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Then I'll go to your place and you can move in with Tom.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Now you know why Miss Sherwood always shows up for breakfast. It's not love it's the coffee machine.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: It's the one task Dickie can do on his own -- make coffee.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Shut up.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Oh darling -- is that for me?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: No it's for Tom as he didn't complain.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I had to promise, capital P, never to take it off -- otherwise I'd give it to you.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Bastard!  Isn't it great, Tom? I found it in Naples. I bargained for about two weeks.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I hope it wasn't cheap.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Oh, it was.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Dubious but special honor, Tom -- crewing Dickie's boat. Alright, bar's open.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Yes please!

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: If you're not at my place by 7.00, Tom and I are running off together.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: He's drowning me!

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: It's always the same whenever someone new comes into his life -- Freddie, Fausto, Peter Smith-Kingsley -- he's wonderful -- did you meet him, he's a musician? -- ...and especially you, of course... and that's only the boys.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Well, she was already dead, darling, wasn't she, so I suppose --

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I don't know why people say this country's civilised. It isn't. It's fucking primitive.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Who's this?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: It's Tom. Tom Ripley. We were at Princeton together.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Okay.  And did we know each other?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Well, I knew you, so I suppose you must have known me.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Princeton is like a fog, America's like a fog.  This is Marge Sherwood. Tom -- sorry, what was it?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Ripley. Hullo. How do you do.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Nothing. Nothing much. Passing through.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Passing through! You're so white. Did you ever see a guy so white, Marge? Gray, actually.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: It's just an undercoat.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Say again?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: You know, a primer.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: That's funny.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Who? Oh, Tom, hello, how are you? We thought you'd disappeared. We were going to send out a search party.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: No, still here.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'm intruding.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Can you mix a martini?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Forging signatures. Telling lies. Impersonating practically anybody.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: That's three. Nobody should have more than one talent. Okay, do an impression.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Now? Okay. Wait a minute. Talent --  The only talent my son has is for cashing his allowance.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: What? What's this?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I like to sail, believe me, I love to sail! Instead I make boats and other people sail them.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Stop! It's too much! You're making all the hairs on my neck stand up!

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Jazz, let's face it, it's just an insolent noise.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I feel like he's here. Horrible. Like the old bastard is here right now! That's brilliant! How do you know him?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I met him in New York.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Marge! You've got to hear this!

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Could you ever conceive of going there, Tom, and bringing him back?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'd pay you. If you would go to Italy and persuade my son to come home. I'd pay you $1000.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I'm never going back!

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: No, I think your mother, her illness --

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: It's got nothing to do with my mother! She's had leukemia for -- ! This is what makes me boil about him! HE wants me back! -- it's got nothing to do with my mother.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I don't know, Dickie, I'm just telling you what I --

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Go back! Go back to New York or call him if you can find a telephone that works, and tell him wild horses wouldn't drag me back to him or his shipyard.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: You like jazz!

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I love jazz.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: This is the best. Marge says she likes jazz, but she things Glenn Miller is jazz.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Bird! Ask me the name of my sailboat --

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I don't know. What's the name of your sailboat?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Bird!

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Good afternoon!

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What time is it?  Oh God! Do you always type your letters?  That should be two Ts.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I can't write and I can't spell. That's the privilege of a first-class education. You're upstairs at the back. I think Ermelinda made the bed up.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: This is so good of you.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Don't say it again. Now you're a Double Agent and we're going to string my Dad along, I was thinking we might buy a little car with the expense money he's sending you. What do you think, Marge... a little Cinquecento with my Dad's money?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: You're a dark horse, Ripley. Engaged?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Your parents met her.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Oh God -- I can just imagine -- if only Dickie would settle down... doesn't every parent deserve a grandchild? Never! I swear on your ring, Marge. I am never going back.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'm doing this wrong, aren't I?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: You're doing great. We'll make a sailor of you yet. You're doing really well.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Could we sail to Venice?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Sure. I love Venice.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I have to go to Venice.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: See Venice and die, isn't that right? Or is it Rome? You do something and die, don't you? Okay, Venice is on the list.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: And Rome.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Do you ski?  Don't tell me -- you're a lost cause! That's the next thing to deal with. We're planning to go to Cortina at Christmas. Excellent skiing. Excellent.  Marge -- Ripley can't ski. We'll have to teach him that, too. Have you ever known such low class?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: You're breaking my ribs!

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: You're breaking my ribs!

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I could fuck this icebox I love it so much.  What were you actually doing in New York?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I played piano in a few places.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: That's one job, you told me a lot of jobs.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: A few places -- that's a few jobs. Anyway, I don't want to think about New York.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: The mysterious Mr Ripley. Marge and I spend hours speculating.  Cold beer. Thank you Dad.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Copy out from here...

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I love the fact you brought Shakespeare with you and no clothes. Ermelinda says you wash the same shirt out every night. Is that true?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: No! I've got more than one shirt!

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: She can do that stuff for you. Anyway, just wear some of my things, wear anything you want, most of it's ancient.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Now your signature.  Not "Dickie". Your signature.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Without the glasses you're not even ugly.  I don't need them because I never read. How do I look.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Like Clark Kent.  Now Superman.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I know. I write like a child.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Pretty vile. See this: The S and the T, do you see? -- fine, vulnerable -- that's pain, that's secret pain.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: It must be a deep secret, cause I don't know about it.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Your handwriting -- nothing more naked. See -- nothing's quite touching the line -- that's vanity.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Well we certainly know that's true.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Do you have any brothers?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: No, no brothers, no sisters.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Me neither. Nor does Marge. All only children -- what does that mean?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Means we never shared a bath. I'm cold. Can I get in?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I didn't mean with you in it.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Okay, you get in. I'm like a prune anyway.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: What does he say?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: He's getting impatient. He wants me to reassure him you'll be home by Thanksgiving.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: You've got to get a new jacket. Really. You must be sick of the same clothes. I'm sick of seeing you in them.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I can't. I can't keep spending your father's money.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I love how responsible you are. My Dad should make you Chief Accountant or something. Let me buy you a jacket. There's a great place when we get to Rome, Batistoni.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Where do we find a carozza for the Forum, or can we hire any of them -- ?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Relax.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: It's just there's so much to do in a single day.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Relax. The most important question is where to eat. I hope Freddie made a reservation.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Freddie?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Freddie Miles. You know -- he's organizing the Cortina skiing trip.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Look, Tom, we've got to go to a club and meet some friends of Freddie's. The best thing is -- if you want to be a tourist -- grab a cab and we can meet up at the railway station.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What club?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Freddie's arranged it with some of the skiing crowd. Come if you want but I thought you wanted to see the Forum...?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I did. And then maybe get the jacket and what have you...

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Shoes too?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: You said I could pick out a jacket and I just... Sorry.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Get undressed in your own room, would you?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I thought you'd missed the train.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Freddie drove me back in his car.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Is Freddie here?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: He's downstairs.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I was just fooling around. Don't say anything. Sorry.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What's the fight about? That's her fiancee, isn't it? Are they blaming him?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I don't know! Why are you asking me?  How can it take an hour to find an ambulance?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: She was pregnant. Did you know that? Do you know what that means in a place like this?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'm prepared to take the blame.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: You've been so good to me. You're the brother I never had. I'm the brother you never had.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: She came to me for help, she needed money, and I didn't help her. I didn't help her. Now she's dead and it's my fault.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'm not going to say anything -- to Marge, or anybody, the police -- It's a secret between us and I'll keep it.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: ...The thousand dollars, of course, was only due in the event that you succeeded in bringing Dickie home. Naturally, I hope the trip has afforded you some pleasure despite the failure of its main objective you need no longer consider yourself obligated to us in any way...

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: You can't blame him. You could hardly expect this to go on forever.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I thought you might write again. Now that we're brothers...

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I can't, how can I, in all decency? We've had a good run, haven't we?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What about Venice? Can we stick to that plan at least?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I don't think so, Tom. You can't stay on here without money. It's time we all moved on. Besides I'm sick of Mongi. Especially now with everything -- I really want to move to the North. I need to check out San Remo next week, find somewhere new to keep the boat. But it would be great, though, if you came with me. Our last trip before you leave. There's a jazz festival -- we could say goodbye in style. What do you think? A last trip?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: To Mongibello and the happiest days of my life.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: To Mongi. You're cheerful tonight.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'm suddenly quite happy to be going back.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: That's good.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I've got plans!

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Ripley's plans.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Esatto. I'm always planning.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Did I know you at Princeton, Tom? I didn't, did I?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Why are you asking all of a sudden?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: No reason. Because you're leaving, I guess. I don't think you were there, were you?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I mean it as a compliment. You've got such great taste, I don't know. Most of the thugs at Princeton had tasted everything and had no taste. Used to say, the cream of America: rich and thick. Freddie's the perfect example.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Then I'll take it as a compliment.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I knew it! I had a bet with Marge!

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Ha.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Do you even like jazz -- or was that something for my benefit?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I've gotten to like it. I've gotten to like everything about the way you live. It's one big love affair. If you knew my life back home in New York...

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I'm thinking of giving up the sax, what do you think about drums?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: So cool.
